direction.raw_text: He is a bespectacled man in his thirties, hale but somewhat bookish. He stands, tuxedoed, in the wings of a theater, looking out at the stage, listening intently to end of a performance. In the shadows behind him an old stagehand leans against a flat, expressionlessly smoking a cigarette, one hand on a thick rope that hangs from the ceiling. The voices of the performing actors echo in from the offscreen stage:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm blowin' out of here, blowin' for good.  I'm kissin' it all goodbye, these four stinkin' walls, the six flights up, the el that roars by at three A.M. like a castiron wind. Kiss 'em goodbye for me, Maury! I'll miss 'em  like hell I will!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dreaming again!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not this time, Lil! I'm awake now, awake for the first time in years. Uncle Dave said it: Daylight is a dream if you've lived with your eyes closed. Well my eyes are open now! I see that choir, and I know they're dressed in rags! But we're part of that choir, both of us  yeah, and you, Maury, and Uncle Dave too!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sun's coming up, kid. They'll be hawking the fish down on Fulton Street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let 'em hawk. Let 'em sing their hearts out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it, kid. Take that ruined choir.  Make it sing!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So long, Maury.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So long. We hear a door open and close, then approaching footsteps. A tall, dark actor in a used tweed suit and carrying a beat-up valise passes in front of Barton: From offscreen stage:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll hear from that kid. And I don't mean a postcard. The actor sets the valise down and then stands waiting int he shadows behind Barton. An older man in work clothes  not wardrobe  passes in front of Barton from the other direction, pauses at the edge of the stage and cups his hands to his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! FRESH FISH! As the man walks back off the screen:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's spit on our hands and get to work.  It's late, Maury.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not any more Lil... Barton mouths the last line in sync with the offscreen actor:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...It's early. With this the stagehand behind Barton furiously pulls the rope hand-over-hand and we hear thunderous applause and shouts of "Bravo!" As the stagehand finishes bringing the curtain down, somewhat muting the applause, the backstage actor trots out of frame toward the stage. The stagehand pulls on an adjacent rope, bringing the curtain back up and unmuting the applause. Barton Fink seems dazed. He has been joined by two other men, both dressed in tuxedos, both beaming toward the stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looking across a tenement set at the backs of the cast as the curtain rises on the enthusiastic house. The actors take their bows and the cry of "Author, Author" goes up from the crowd. The actors turn to smile at Barton in the wings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hesitates, unable to take it all in. He is gently nudged toward the stage by the two tuxedoed gentlemen. As he exits toward the stage the applause is deafening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pushing a maitre 'd who looks back over his shoulder as he leads the way through the restaurant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your table is ready, Monsieur Fink... several members of your party have already arrived...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pulling Barton
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is Garland Stanford here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He called to say he'd be a few minutes late... Ah, here we are...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: IN Toward a large semi-circular booth. Three guests, two me and a woman in evening wear, are rising and beaming at Barton. A fat middle-aged man, one of the tuxedoed gentlemen we saw backstage, is moving out to let Barton slide in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton, Barton, so glad you could make it.  You know Richard St. Claire... Barton nods and looks at the woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and Poppy Carnahan. We're drinking champagne, dear boy, in honor of the occasion. Have you seen the Herald? Barton looks sullenly at his champagne glass as the fat man fills it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I don't want to embarrass you but Caven could hardly contain himself. But more important, Richard and Poppy here loved the play.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Loved it! What power!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, it was a corker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Richard, but I know for a fact the only fish you've ever seen were tacked to a the wall of the yacht club.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ouch!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bravo! Nevertheless, we were all devastated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Weeping! Copius tears! What did the Herald say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I happen to have it with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please Derek POPPY Do read it, do!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Bare Ruined Choirs: Triumph of the Common Man. The star of the Bare Ruined Choirs was not seen on the stage of the Belasco last night though the thespians involved all acquitted themselves admirably. The find of the evening was the author of this drama about simple folk fish mongers, in fact  whose brute struggle for existence cannot quite quell their longing for something higher. The playwright finds nobility in the most squalid corners and poetry in the most callused speech. A tough new voice in the American theater has arrived, and the owner of that voice is named... Barton Fink."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'll be wrapping fish in it in the morning so I guess it's not a total waste.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cynic!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well we can enjoy your success, Barton, even if you can't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't get me wrong  I'm glad it'll do well for you, Derek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry about me, dear boy  I want you to celebrate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, but I can't start listening to the critics, and I can't kid myself about my own work. A writer writes from his gut, and his gut tells him what's good and what's... merely adequate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well I don't pretend to be a critic, but Lord, I have a gut, and it tells me it was simply marvelous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And a charming gut it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You dog!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aaa-woooooooo! Barton turns to look for the source of an insistent jingling. We swish pan off him to find a busboy marching through the restaurant displaying a page sign, bell attached, with Barton's name on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A distinguished fifty-year-old gentleman in evening clothes is nursing a martini, watching Barton approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he draws near.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you were going to join us. Jesus, Garland, you left me alone with those people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't panic, I'll join you in a minute.  What's you think of Richard and Poppy? Barton scowls
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The play was marvelous. She wept, copiously. Millions of dollars and no sense. Garland smiles, then draws Barton close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have to talk a little business. I've just been on the phone to Los Angeles.  Barton, Capitol Pictures wants to put you under contract. They've offered you a thousand dollars a week. I think I can get them to go as high as two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To do what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you do far a living?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not sure anymore. I guess I try to make a difference.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fair enough. No pressure here, Barton, because I respect you, but let me point out a couple of things. One, here you make a difference to five hundred fifty people a night  if the show sells out.  Eighty five million people go to the pictures every week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To see pap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, generally, to see pap. However, point number two: A brief tenure in Hollywood could support you through the writing of any number of plays.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, Garland; my place is here right now. I feel I'm on the brink of success-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd say you're already enjoying some. Barton leans earnestly forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Garland, don't you see? Not the kind of success where the critics fawn over you or the producers like Derek make a lot of money. No, a real success  the success we've been dreaming about  the creation of a new, living theater of, about, and for the common man! If I ran off to Hollywood now I'd be making money, going to parties, meeting the big shots, sure, but I'd be cutting myself off from the wellspring of that success, from the common man. He leans back and chuckles ruefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I guess I'm sprouting off again. But I am certain of this, Garland: I'm capable of more good work. Maybe better work than I did in Choirs. It just doesn't seem to me that Los Angeles is the place to lead the life of mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay Barton, you're the artist, I'm just the ten percenter. You decide what you want and I'll make it happen. I'm only asking that your decision be informed by a little realism  if I can use that word and Hollywood in the same breath. Barton glumly lights a cigarette and gazes out across the floor. Garland studies him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Look, they love you, kid everybody does. You see Caven's review in the Herald?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, what did it say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take my copy. You're the toast of Broadway and you have the opportunity to redeem that for a little cash strike that, a lot of cash. Garland looks at Barton for a reaction, but gets none.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...The common man'll still be here when you get back. What the hell, they might even have one or two of 'em out in Hollywood. Absently:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...That's a rationalization, Garland. Garland smiles gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton, it was a joke. We hear a distant rumble. It builds slowly and we cut to:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crushing against the Pacific shore. The roar of the surf slips away as we dissolve to:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A high wide shot from the front door, looking down across wilting potted palms, brass cuspidors turning green, ratty wing chairs; the fading decor is deco-gone-to-seed. Amber light, afternoon turning to evening, slopes in from behind us, washing the derelict lobby with golden highlights. Barton Fink enters frame from beneath the camera and stops in the middle foreground to look across the lobby. We are framed on his back, his coat and hat. The lobby is empty.  There is a suspended beat as Barton takes it in. Barton moves toward the front desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Barton stops at the empty desk. He hits a small silver bell next to the register. Its ring-out goes on and on without losing volume. After a long beat there is a dull scuffle of shoes on stairs. Barton, puzzled, looks around the empty lobby, then down at the floor behind the front desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It swings open and a young man in a faded maroon uniform, holding a shoebrush and a shoe  not one of his own  climbs up from the basement. He closes the trap door, steps up to the desk and sticks his finger out to touch the small silver bell, finally muting it. The lobby is now silent again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome to the Hotel Earle. May I help you, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm checking in. Barton Fink. The clerk flips through cards on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Fink, Barton. That must be you, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Must be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay then, everything seems to be in order. Everything seems to be in order. He is turning to a register around for Barton to sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Are you a tranz or a rez?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Transient or resident?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know... I mean, I'll be here, uh, indefinitely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rez. That'll be twenty-five fifty a week payable in advance. Checkout time is twelve sharp, only you can forget that on account you're a rez. If you need anything, anything at all, you dial zero on your personal in-room telephone and talk to me. My name is Chet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm going to be working here, mostly at night; I'm a writer. Do you have room service?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kitchen closes at eight but I'm the night clerk. I can always ring out for sandwiches. The clerk is scribbling something on the back of an index card.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Though we provide privacy for the residential guest, we are also a full service hotel including complimentary shoe shine. My name is Chet. He pushes a room key across the counter on top of the index card. Barton looks at the card. On it: "CHET!" Barton looks back up at the clerk. They regard each other for a beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Okay
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh? The clerk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okey-dokey, go ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What CLERK Don't you wanna go to your room?! Barton stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...What number is it? The clerk stares back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Six-oh-five. I forgot to tell you. As Barton stoops to pick up his two small bags:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Those your only bags?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others are being sent. The clerk leans over the desk to call after him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll keep an eye out for them. I'll keep my eyes peeled, Mr. Fink. Barton is walking to the elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton enters and sets down his bags. An aged man with white stubble, wearing a greasy maroon uniform, sits on a stool facing the call panel. He does not acknowledge Barton's presence. After a beat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Six, please. The elevator man gets slowly to his feet. As he pushes the door closed:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Next stop: Six.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton walks slowly toward us, examining the numbers on the doors. The long, straight hallway is carpeted with an old stained forest green carpet. The wallpaper shows faded yellowing palm trees.  Barton sticks his key in the lock of a door midway down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Barton enters. The room is small and cheaply furnished. There is a lumpy bed with a worn yellow coverlet, an old secretary table, and a wooden luggage stand. As Barton crosses the room we follow to reveal a sink and wash basin, a house telephone on a rickety night stand, and a window with yellowing sheers looking on an air shaft. Barton throws his valise onto the bed where it sinks, jittering.  He shrugs off his jacket. Pips of sweat stand out on Barton's brow. The room is hot. He walks across the room, switches on an oscillating fan and struggles to throw open the window. After he strains at it for a moment, it slides open with a great wrenching sound. Barton picks up his Underwood and places it on the secretary table. He gives the machine a casually affectionate pat. Next to the typewriter are a few sheets of house stationary: "THE HOTEL EARLE: A DAY OR A LIFETIME." We pan up to a picture in a cheap wooden frame on the wall above the desk. A bathing beauty sits on the beach under a cobalt blue sky. One hand shields her eyes from the sun as she looks out at a crashing surf. The sound of the surf mixes up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looking at the picture
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The surf mixes up louder. We hear a gull cry. The sound snaps off with the ring of a telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the nightstand next to the bed. With a groan of bedsprings Barton sits into frame and picks up the telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How d'ya like your room!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Who is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chet!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chet! From downstairs! Barton wearily rubs the bridge of his nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...How d'ya like your room!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Barton's head drops down into frame against it. He reaches over and turns off the bedside light. He lies back and closes his eyes. A long beat. We hear a faint hum, growing louder. Barton opens his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A naked, peeling ceiling.  The hum  a mosquito, perhaps stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes move this way and that. After a silent beat, he shuts them again. After another silent beat, we hear  muffled, probably from am adjacent room  a brief, dying laugh. It is sighing and weary, like the end of a laughing fit, almost a sob. Silence again. We hear the rising mosquito hum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton Fink is ushered into a large, light office by an obsequious middle- aged man in a sagging suit. There are mosquito bites on Barton's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From behind a huge white desk, a burly man in an expensive suit gets to his feet and strides across the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that him?! Barton Fink?!  Lemme put my arms around this guy! He bear-hugs Barton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...How the hell are ya? Good trip? He separates without waiting for an answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name is Jack Lipnik. I run this dump. You know that  you read the papers. Lipnik is lumbering back to his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lou treating you all right? Got everything you need?  What the hell's the matter with your face? What the hell's the matter with his face, Lou?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not as bad as it looks; just a mosquito in my room LIPNIK Place okay? To Lou:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Where did we put him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm at the Earle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never heard of it. Let's move him to the Grand, or the Wilshire, or hell, he can stay at my place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, but I wanted a place that was less...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Less Hollywood?  Sure, say it, it's not a dirty word. Sat whatever the hell you want. The writer is king here at Capitol Pictures. You don't believe me, take a look at your paycheck at the end of every week that's what we think of the writer. (to Lou) ...so what kind of pictures does he like?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Fink hasn't given a preference, Mr.  Lipnik.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's about it, Bart?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To be honest, I don't go to the pictures much, Mr. Lipnik LIPNIK That's okay, that's okay, that's okay  that's just fine. You probably just walked in here thinking that was going to be a handicap, thinking we wanted people who knew something about the medium, maybe even thinking there was all kind of technical mumbo- jumbo to learn. You were dead wrong. We're only interested in one thing: Can you tell a story, Bart?  Can you make us laugh, can you make us cry, can you make us wanna break out in joyous song? Is that more than one thing? Okay.  The point is, I run this dump and I don't know the technical mumbo-jumbo. Why do I run it? I've got horse-sense, goddamnit. Showmanship. And also, and I hope Lou told you this, I bigger and meaner than any other kike in this town. Did you tell him that, Lou? And I don't mean my dick's bigger than yours, it's not a sexual thing although, you're the writer, you would know more about that. Coffee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Yes, thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lou. Lou immediately rises and leaves. Lipnik's tone becomes confidential:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...He used to have shares in the company.  An ownership interest. Got bought out in the twenties  muscled out according to some. Hell, according to me. So we keep him around, he's got a family. Poor schmuck. He's sensitive, don't mention the old days. Oh hell, say whatever you want. Look, barring a preference, Bart, we're gonna put you to work on a wrestling picture. Wallace Beery. I say this because they tell me you know the poetry of the street. That would rule out westerns, pirate pictures, screwball, Bible, Roman... He rises and starts pacing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But look, I'm not one of these guys thinks poetic has gotta be fruity. We're together on that, aren't we? I mean I'm from New York myself  well, Minsk if you wanna go way back, which we won't if you don't mind and I ain't askin'. Now people're gonna tell you, wrestling. Wallace Beery, it's a B picture. You tell them, bullshit. We don't make B pictures here at Capitol.  Let's put a stop to that rumor right now. Lou enters with coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Thanks Lou. Join us. Join us. Talking about the Wallace Beery picture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excellent picture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We got a treatment on it yet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not yet Jack. We just bought the story. Saturday Evening Post.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, the hell with the story. Wallace Beery is a wrestler. I wanna know his hopes, his dreams. Naturally, he'll have to get mixed up with a bad element. And a romantic interest. You know the drill.  Romantic interest, or else a young kid. An orphan. What do you think, Lou? Wally a little too old for a romantic interest?  Look at me, a writer in the room and I'm askin' Lou what the goddamn story should be! After a robust laugh, he beams at Barton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Well Bart, which is it? Orphan? Dame?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Both maybe? There is a disappointed silence. Lipnik looks at Lou.  Lou clears his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Maybe we should do a treatment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, hell, let Bart take a crack at it.  He'll get into the swing of things or I don't know writers. Let's make it a dame, Bart, keep it simple. We don't gotta tackle the world our first time out. The important thing is we all have that Barton Fink feeling, but since you're Barton Fink I'm assuming you have it in spades.  Seriously Bart, I like you. We're off to a good start. Dammit, if all our writers were like you I wouldn't have to get so goddamn involved. I'd like to see something by the end of the week. Lou is getting to his feet and signaling for Barton to do likewise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Heard about your show, by the way. My man in New York saw it. Tells me it was pretty damn powerful. Pretty damn moving.  A little fruity, he said, but I guess you know what you're doing. Thank you for your heart. We need more heart in pictures.  We're all expecting great things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are in the sixth-floor hallway of the Earle, late at night. A pair of shoes sits before each door. Faintly, from one of the rooms, we can hear the clack. clack. clack. of a typewriter. It grows louder as we track forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: TYPEWRITER Close on the typing so that we see only each letter as it is typed, without context. One by one the letters clack on: a-u-d-i-b-l-e. After a short beat, a period strikes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elbows on his desk, he looks down at what he has just written. He rolls the paper up a few lines, looks some more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On Manhattan's Lower East Side. Early morning traffic is audible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a beat he rolls the sheet back into place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The letter-strike area. It is lined up to the last period, which is struck over by a comma. The words "as is" are typed in and we cut back to BARTON as he continues typing. He stops after several more characters and looks. Silence. Breaking the silence, muffled laughter from an adjacent room. A man's laughter. It is weary, solitary, mirthless. Barton looks up at the wall directly in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The picture of the girl on the beach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Staring, as the end-of-the-tether laughing continues. Barton looks back down at his typewriter as if to resume work, but the sound is too insistent to ignore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The room, Barton sitting at his desk, staring at the wall. The laughter. Barton pushes his chair back, goes to the door, opens it and looks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The empty hallway, a pair of shoes before each door. At the end of the hall a dim red bulb burns over the door to the staircase, punctuating the sick yellow glow of the line of wall sconces. The laughter, though still faint, is more resonant in the empty hall. Perhaps its quality has changed, or perhaps simply because it is so insistent, the laughter now might be taken for weeping. Barton pauses, trying to interpret the sound. He slowly withdraws into his room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton looks down at his typewriter for a beat. The laughter/weeping continues. He walks over to his bed, sits down and picks up the house phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello... Chet? This is Barton Fink in room 605. Yes, there's uh, there's someone in the room next door to mine, 604, and he's uh... He's uh... making a lot of... noise. After a beat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Thank you. He cradles the phone. The laughter continues for a moment or two, then abruptly stops with the muffled sound of the telephone ringing next door. Barton looks at the wall. The muffled sound of a man talking. The sound of the earpiece being pronged. Muffled footsteps next door. The sound of the neighbor's door opening and shutting. Footsteps approaching the hall. A hard, present knock at Barton's door. Barton hesitates for a beat, then rises to go get the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Barton opens it. Standing in the hall is a large man  a very large man  in short sleeves, suspenders, and loosened tie. His face is slightly flushed, with the beginnings of sweat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you... Somebody just complained... Hastily:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I didn't  I mean, I did call down, not to complain exactly, I was just concerned that you might  not that it's my business, but that you might be in some kind of... distress. You see, I was trying to work, and it's, well, it was difficult MAN Yeah. I'm damn sorry, if I bothered you.  The damn walls here, well, I just apologize like hell... He sticks his hand out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...My name's Charlie Meadows. I guess we're neighbors... Without reaching for the hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton Fink. Unfazed, Charlie Meadows unpockets a flask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neighbor, I'd feel better about the damned inconvenience if you'd let me buy you a drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all right, really, thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, hell, you trying to work and me carrying on in there. Look, the liquor's good, wuddya say? As he enters:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... You got a glass? It's the least I can do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay... a quick one, sure... He gets two glasses from the wash basin.  Charlie sits down on the edge of the bed and uncorks his flask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, just a nip. I feel like hell, all the carryings-on next door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's okay, I assure you. It's just that I was trying to work CHARLIE What kind of work do you do, Barton, if you don't mind my asking?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm a writer, actually.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't say. That's a tough racket. My hat's off to anyone who can make a go of it. Damned interesting work, I'd imagine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can be. Not easy, but CHARLIE Damned difficult, I'd imagine. As he hands Charlie a glass:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what's your line, Mr. Meadows?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell no! Call me Charlie. Well Barton, you might say I sell peace of mind. Insurance is my game  door-to-door, human contact, still the only way to move merchandise. He fills a glass with whiskey and swaps it for the empty glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...In spite of what you might think from tonight, I'm pretty good at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doesn't surprise me at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell yes. Because I believe in it. Fire, theft, and casualty are not things that only happen to other people  that's what I tell 'em. Writing doesn't work out, you might want to look into it. Providing for basic human need  a fella could do worse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, I'll keep it in mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of scribbler are you newspaperman did you say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm actually writing for the pictures now CHARLIE Pictures! Jesus! He guffaws.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I'm sorry, brother, I was just sitting here thinking I was talking to some ambitious youngster, eager to make good.  Hell, you've got it made! Writing for pictures! Beating out that competition!  And me being patronizing! He gestures toward his face:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Is the egg showing or what?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's okay; actually I am just starting out in the movies  though I was pretty well established in New York, some renown there,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, it's an exciting time then. I'm not the best-read mug on the planet, so I guess it's no surprise I didn't recognize your name. Jesus, I feel like a heel. For the first time Barton smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's okay, Charlie. I'm a playwright. My shows've only played New York. Last one got a hell of a write-up in the Herald. I guess that's why they wanted me here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell, why not? Everyone wants quality. What kind of venue, that is to say, thematically, uh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do I write about? Charlie laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Caught me trying to be fancy! Yeah, that's it, Bart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's a good question. Strange as it may seem, Charlie, I guess I write about people like you. The average working stiff. The common man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well ain't that a kick in the head!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I guess it is. But in a way, that's exactly the point. There's a few people in New York  hopefully our numbers are growing  who feel we have an opportunity now to forge something real out of everyday experience, create a theater for the masses that's based on a few simple truths  not on some shopworn abstractions about drama that doesn't hold true today, if they ever did... He gazes at Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I don't guess this means much to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell, I could tell you some stories
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that's the point, that we all have stories. The hopes and dreams of the common man are as noble as those of any king. It's the stuff of life  why shouldn't it be the stuff of theater?  Goddamnit, why should that be a hard pill to swallow? Don't call it new theater, Charlie; call it real theater. Call it our theater.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can see you feel pretty strongly about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I don't mean to get up on my high horse, but why shouldn't we look at ourselves up there?  Who cares about the Fifth Earl of Bastrop and Lady Higginbottom and  and and who killed Nigel Grinch-Gibbons?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can feel my butt getting sore already.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly, Charlie! You understand what I'm saying  a lot more than some of these literary types. Because you're a real man!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I could tell you some stories BARTON Sure you could!  And yet many writers do everything in their power to insulate themselves from the common man  from where they live, from where they trade, from where they fight and love and converse and and  and... so naturally their work suffers, and regresses into empty formalism and  well, I'm spouting off again, but to put it in your language, the theater becomes as phony as a three dollar bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I guess that's tragedy right there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frequently played, seldom remarked. Charlie laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever that means. Barton smiles with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're all right, Charlie. I'm glad you stopped by. I'm sorry if  well I know I sometimes run on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell no! Jesus, I'm the kind of guy, I'll let you know if I'm bored. I find it all pretty damned interesting. I'm the kind schmoe who's generally interested in the other guy's point of view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, we've got something in common then. Charlie is getting to his feet and walking to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well Christ, if there's any way I can contribute, or help, or whatever Barton chuckles and extends his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, sure Charlie, you can help by just being yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I can tell you some stories He pumps Barton's hand, then turns and pauses in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...And look, I'm sorry as hell about the interruption. Too much revelry late at night, you forget there are other people in the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See you, Charlie. Charlie closes the door and is gone. Barton goes back to his desk and sits. Muffled, we can hear the door of the adjacent room opening and closing. Barton looks at the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bathing beauty. From offscreen we hear a sticky, adhesive-giving-way sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks around to the opposite bed  wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wallpaper is lightly sheened with moisture from the heat. One swath of wallpaper is just finishing sagging away from the wall. About three feet of the wall, where it meets the ceiling, is exposed. The strip of wallpaper, its glue apparently melted, sags and nods above the bed. It glistens yellow, like a fleshy tropical flower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes over to the bed and steps up onto it. He smooths the wallpaper back up against the wall. He looks at his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sticky with tacky yellow wall sweat. He wipes it onto his shirt. We hear a faint mosquito hum. Barton looks around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whirring at high speed. The keys strike too quickly for us to make out the words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On Barton, sitting on a couch in an office anteroom, staring blankly.  Distant phones ring. Barton's eyes are tired and bloodshot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A gargoyle secretary sits typing a document. The office door opens in the background and a short middle- aged man in a dark suit emerges. To his secretary:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm eating on the lot today He notices Barton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Who's he? The secretary looks over from her typing to consult a slip of paper on her desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton Fink, Mr. Geisler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a writer, Mr. Geisler. Ted Okum said I should drop by morning to see you about the GEISLER Ever act?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Huh? No, I'm GEISLER We need Indians for a Norman Steele western.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a writer. Ted O GEISLER Think about it, Fink. Writers come and go; we always need Indians.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a writer. Ted Okum said you're producing this Wallace Beery picture I'm working on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What!?  Ted Okum doesn't know shit. They've assigned me enough pictures for a goddamn year. What Ted Okum doesn't know you could almost squeeze into the Hollywood Bowl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then who should I talk to? Geisler gives a hostile stare. Without looking at her, he addresses the secretary:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get me Lou Breeze. He perches on the edge of the desk, an open hand out toward the secretary, as he glares wordlessly at Barton. After a moment:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he in for Mr. Geisler? She puts the phone in Geisler's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lou? How's Lipnik's ass smell this morning?... Yeah?... Yeah?... Okay, the reason I'm calling, I got a writer here, Fink, all screwy. Says I'm producing that Wallace Beery wrestling picture  what'm I, the goddamn janitor around here?...  Yeah, well who'd you get that from?...  Yeah, well tell Lipnik he can kiss my dimpled ass... Shit! No, alright... No, no, all right. Without looking he reaches the phone back. The secretary takes it and cradles it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Okay kid, let's chow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton and Geisler sit eating in a semicircular booth. Geisler speaks through a mouthful of food:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry about it. It's just a B picture. I bring it in on budget, they'll book it without even screening it. Life is too short.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Lipnik said he wanted to look at the script, see something by the end of the week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure he did. And he forgot about it before your ass left his sofa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. I'm just having trouble getting started. It's funny, I'm blocked up. I feel like I need some kind of indication of... what's expected GEISLER Wallace Beery. Wrestling picture. What do you need, a road map? Geisler chews on his cottage cheese and stares at Barton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Look, you're confused? You need guidance? Talk to another writer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who? Geisler rises and throws his napkin onto his plate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, throw a rock in here, you'll hit one. And do me a favor, Fink: Throw it hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton stands at a urinal. He stares at the wall in front of him as he pees. After a moment, he cocks his head, listening. We hear a throat clearing, as if by a tenor preparing for a difficult passage. It is followed by the gurgling ruch of vomit. Barton buttons his pants and turns to face the stalls. There is more businesslike throat clearing. Barton stoops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We boom down to show the blue serge pants and well-polished shoes of the stall's kneeling occupant. A white handkerchief has been spread on the floor to protect the trouser knees. The toilet flushes. The man rises, picks up his handkerchief up off the floor and gives it a smart flap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He quickly straightens and goes to the sink. He starts washing his hands. We hear the stall door being unlatched. Barton glances over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The stall door opening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quickly, self-consciously, he looks back down at his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His hands writhing under the running water. We hear footsteps approaching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forcing himself to look at his hands. We hear the man reach the adjacent sink and turn on the tap. Barton can't help glancing up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A dapper little man in a neat blue serge suit. He has warm brown eyes, a patrician nose, and a salt-and-pepper mustache. He smiles pleasantly at Barton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives a nervous smile  more like a tic  and looks back down at his hands. We hear the man gargling water and spitting into the sink. After a moment, Barton looks up again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reacting to barton's look as he washes his hands. This time, a curt nod accompanies his pleasant smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks back down, then up again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Extends a dripping hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill Mayhew. Sorry about the odor. His speech is softly accented, from the South.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton Fink. They shake, then return to their ablutions. We hold on Barton as we hear Mayhew's faucet being turned off and his foot-steps receding. For some reason, Barton's eyes are widening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Jesus. W.P.! The dapper little man stops and turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I beg your pardon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .P. Mayhew? The writer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just Bill, please. Barton stands with his back to the sink, facing the little man, his hands dripping onto the floor. There is a short pause. Barton is strangely agitated, his voice halting but urgent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill!... Mayhew cocks his head with a politely patient smile. Finally Barton brings out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...You're the finest novelist of our time. Mayhew leans against a stall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why thank you, son, how kind. Bein' occupied here in the worship of Mammon, I haven't had the chance yet to see your play He smiles at Barton's surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Yes, Mistuh Fink, some of the news reaches us in Hollywood. He is taking out a flask and unscrewing its lid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, I'm flattered that you even recognize my name. My God, I had no idea you were in Hollywood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of us undomesticated writers eventually make their way out here to the Great Salt Lick. Mebbe that's why I allus have such a powerful thrust. He clears his throat, takes a swig from the flask, and waves it at Barton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...A little social lubricant, Mistuh Fink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's still a little early for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So be it. He knocks back some more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Bill, if I'm imposing you should say so, I know you're very busy  I just, uh... I just wonder if I could ask you a favor... That is to say, uh... have you ever written a wrestling picture? Mayhew eyes him appraisingly, and at length clears his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...You are drippin', suh. Barton looks down at his hands, then pulls a rough brown paper towel from a dispenser. Mayhew sighs:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Mistuh Fink, they have not invented a genre of picture that Bill Mayhew has not, at one time or othuh, been invited to essay. I have taken my stabs at the wrastlin' form, as I have stabbed at so many others, and with as little success. I gather that you are a fresh-man here, eager for an upperclassman's council. However, just at the moment... He waves his flask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I have drinkin' to do. Why don't you stop at my bungalow, which is numbah fifteen, later on this afternoon... He turns to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and we will discuss wrastlin' scenarios and other things lit'rary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are close on brass numerals tacked up on a white door. Muted, from inside, we hear Mayhew's voice  enraged, bellowing.  We hear things breaking. Softer, we hear a woman's voice, its tone placating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SLOWLY IN On Barton, standing in front of the door. The noise abates for a moment. We hear the woman's voice again. Barton hesitates, listening; he thinks, decides, knocks. With this the woman's voice stops, and Mayhew starts wailing again. The door cracks open. The woman looks as if she has been crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Can I help you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, I... My name is Fink... Uh, Bill asked me to drop by this afternoon.  Is he in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Mayhew is indisposed at the moment From inside, we hear Mayhew's wail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: !! WHERE'S M'HONEY!! The woman glances uncomfortably over her shoulder and steps outside, closing the door behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Fink, I'm Audrey Taylor, Mr. Mayhew's personal secretary. I know this all must sound horrid. I really do apologize... Through the door Mayhew is still wailing piteously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is, uh... Is he okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He will be... When he can't write, he drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! WHERE'S M'HONEY!! She brushes a wisp of hair out of her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am sorry, it's so embarassing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about you? Will you be alright?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be fine... Are you a writer, Mr Fink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes I am. I'm working on a wres please call me Barton. Audrey reaches out and touches Barton's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll tell Bill you dropped by. I'm sure he'll want to reschedule your appointment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps you and I could get together at some point also. I'm sorry if that sounds abrupt. I just... I don't know anyone here in this town. Audrey smiles at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps the three of us, Mr. Fink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Barton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton. You see, Barton, I'm not just Bill's secretary  Bill and I are... I love. We-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: !! WHERE'S M'HONEY!! Audrey glances back as we hear the sound of shattering dishes and heavy footsteps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I know this must look... funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no Hurriedly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We need each other. We give each other...  the things we need VOICE M'HONEY!!... bastard-ass sons of bitches... the water's lappin' up...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, Mr. Fink. Please don't judge us. Please... Flustered, she backs away and closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hand-printed on the package is the message: "Hope these will turn the trick, Mr. Fink.  Chet!" The wrapping is torn away and the small box is opened. Two thumbtacks are taken out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Late at night. The swath of wallpaper behind the bed has sagged away from the wall again, and has been joined by the swath next to it. Barton enters frame and steps up onto the bed. He smooths up the first swath and pushes in a thumbtack near the top.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the tack. As Barton applies pressure to push it in, tacky yellow goo oozes out of the puncture hole and beads around the tack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smoothing up the second swath. As he pushes in the second tack he pauses, listening. Muffled, through the wall, we can hear a woman moaning. After a motionless beat, Barton eases his ear against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As his ear meets the wall. The woman's moaning continues. We hear the creaking of bedsprings and her partner, incongruously giggling. Barton grimaces, gets down off the bed and crosses to the secretary, where he sits. He stares at the paper in the carriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The blank part of the page around the key-strike area, under the metal prongs that hold the paper down. We begin to hear moaning again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still looking; sweating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tracking in on the paper, losing the prongs from frame so that we are looking at the pure unblemished white of the page. The moaning is cut short by two sharp knocks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As it swings open.  Charlie Meadows leans in, smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Howdy, neighbor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie. How are you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus, I hope I'm not interrupting you again. I heard you walking around in here.  Figured I'd drop by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, come in Charlie. Hadn't really gotten started yet  what happened to your ear? for Charle's left ear is plugged with cotton wadding. As he enters:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yeah. An ear infection, chronic thing.  Goes away for a while, but it always comes back. Gotta put cotton in it to staunch the flow of pus. Don't worry, it's not contagious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seen a doctor? Charlie gives a dismissive wave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, doctors. What's he gonna tell me?  Can't trade my head in for a new one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I guess you're stuck with the one you've got. Have a seat. Charlie perches on the corner of the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, I'd invite you over to my place, but it's a goddamn mess. You married, Bart?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I myself have yet to be lassoed. He takes his flask out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Got a sweetheart?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... I guess it's something about my work. I get so worked up over it, I don't know; I don't really have a lot of attention left over, so it would be a little unfair...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, the ladies do ask for attention. In my experience, they pretend to give it, but it's generally a smoke- screen for demanding it back  with interest. How about family, Bart? How're you fixed in that department? Barton smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My folks live in Brooklyn, with my uncle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mine have passed on. It's just the three of us now... He taps himself on the head, chuckling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...What's the expression  me myself and I.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, that's tough, but in a sense, we're all alone in this world aren't we Charlie?  I'm often surrounded by family and friends, but... He shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mm... You're no stranger to loneliness, then. I guess I got no beef; especially where the dames are concerned. In my line of work I get opportunities galore  always on the wing, you know what I'm saying. I could tell stories to curl your hair but it looks like you've already heard 'em! He laughs at his reference to Barton's curly hair, and pulls a dog-eared photograph from his wallet. As he hands it to Barton:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...That's me in Kansas City, plying my trade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie smiles and waves with one foot up on the running board of a 1939 roadster. A battered leather briefcase dangles from one hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...It was taken by one of my policy holders. They're more than just customers to me, Barton.  They really appreciate what I have to offer them. Ya see, her hubby was out of town at the time BARTON You know, in a way, I envy you Charlie.  Your daily routine  you know what's expected. You know the drill. My job is to plumb the depths, so to speak, dredge something up from inside, something honest. There's no road map for that territory... He looks from Charlie to the Underwood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and exploring it can be painful. The kind of pain most people don't know anything about. He looks back at Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...This must be boring you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all. It's damned interesting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah... He gives a sad chuckle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Probably sounds a little grand coming from someone who's writing a wrestling picture for Wallace Beery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beery! You got no beef there! He's good.  Hell of an actor  though, for my money, you can't beat Jack Oakie. A stitch, Oakie. Funny stuff, funny stuff. But don't get me wrong Beery, a wrestling picture, that could be a pip. Wrestled some myself back in school. I guess you know the basic moves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nope, never watched any. I'm not that interested in the act itself CHARLIE Okay, but hell, you should know what it is. I can show you in about thirty seconds. He is getting down on his hands and knees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...You're a little out of your weight class, but just for purposes of demonstration BARTON That's all right, really CHARLIE Not a bit of it, compadre! Easiest thing in the world! You just get down on your knees to my left, slap your right hand here... He indicated his own right bicep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and your left hand here. He indicated his left bicep. Barton hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...You can do it, champ! Barton complies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...All right now, when I say "Ready... wrestle!"  you try and pin me, and I try and pin you. That's the whole game. Got it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Yeah, okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ready... wrestle! With one clean move Charlie flips Barton onto his back, his head and shoulders hitting with a thump. Charlie pins Barton's shoulders with his own upper body. But before the move even seems completed Charlie is standing again, offering his hand down to Barton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn, there I go again. We're gonna wake the downstairs neighbors.  I didn't hurt ya, did I? Barton seems dazed, but not put out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay, it's okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's all that wrestling is. Except usually there's more grunting and squirming before the pin. Well, it's your first time. And you're out of your weight class. Barton has propped himself up and is painfully massaging the back of his head. This registers on Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Jesus, I did hurt you! He clomps hurriedly away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I'm just a big, clumsy lug. I sure do apologize. We hear water running, and Charlie reenters with a wet towel. Barton accepts the towel and presses it to his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...You sure you're okay? Barton gets to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine, Charlie. Really I am. Actually, it's been helpful, but I guess I should get back to work. Charlie looks at him with some concern, then turns and heads for the door.

direction.raw_text: ...Don't feel bad, though. I wouldn't be much of a match for you at mental gymnastics. Gimme a holler if you need anything. The door closes. Barton crosses to the secretary and sits down, rubbing the back of his head. He rolls up the carriage and looks at the page in the typewriter.

direction.raw_text: On Manhattan's Lower East Side. Early morning traffic is audible, as is the cry fishmongers.

direction.raw_text: Barton enters. The sink, which Charlie apparently left running when he wet Barton's towel, is overflowing. Water spills onto the tile floor. Barton hurriedly shuts off the tap, rolls up one sleeve and reaches into the sink. As his hand emerges, holding something, we hear the unclogged sink gulp water.

direction.raw_text: .P. Mayhew" A hand enters with pen to inscribe: "To Barton May this little entertainment divert you in your sojourn among the Philistines.   Bill" The book is closed and picked up.

direction.raw_text: R As-thoomp!-the heavy volume is deposited across the table, in front of Barton, by Mayhew. Barton, Mayhew, and Audrey are seated around a picnic table. It is one of a few tables littering the lot of a small stucco open-air hamburger stand. It is peaceful early evening. The last of the sunlight slopes down through palm trees. Barton, Mayhew, and Audrey are the only customers at the stand. Mayhew's black Ford stands alone at the edge of the lot. Mayhew leans back in his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I close m'eyes I can almost smell the live oak.

direction.raw_text: That's hamburger grease, Bill.

direction.raw_text: Well... actually, no Bill... Barton looks nervously at Audrey before continuing.

direction.raw_text: ...No, I've always found that writing comes from a great inner pain. Maybe it's a pain that comes from a realization that one must do something for one's fellow man  to help somehow to ease his suffering.  Maybe it's a personal pain. At any rate, I don't believe good work is possible without it.

direction.raw_text: Mmm. Wal, me, I just enjoy maikn' things up. Yessir. Escape... It's when I can't write, can't escape m'self, that I want to tear m'head off and run screamin' down the street with m'balls in a fruitpickers pail. Mm... He sighs and reaches for a bottle of Wild Turkey.

We are pulling back from the white, past the metal prongs of the key-strike area on a typewriter. More letters appear rapid-fire, growing smaller as the pull back continues. direction.raw_text: He screams. He screams again. We hear rapid and heavy footfalls next door, a door opening and closing, and then a loud banging on Barton's door. Barton's head spins towards the door. He is momentarily frozen. Another knock. Barton leaps to his feet and hurries to the door.

direction.raw_text: Are you sure BARTON No... no... Barton is nodding as he shuts the door in Charlie's face. He walks back into the room.

Jesus, if I hadn't been honest in my business dealings  well, of course, you can't always be honest, not with the sharks swimming around this town but if you're a writer, you don't think about those things  if I'd been totally honest, I wouldn't be within a mile of this pool  unless I was cleaning it. But that's no reason for you not to be. Honest, I mean.  Not cleaning the pool. Lou has entered with a drink, which he sets next to Barton. Lou sits. Barton looks around, takes the drink, sips at it greedily, but must finally take the plunge.

direction.raw_text: Well... to be honest, I'm never really comfortable discussing a work in progress.  I've got it all worked out in my head, but sometimes if you force it out in words  prematurely the wrong words  well, your meaning changes, and it changes your own mind, and you never get it back  so I'd just as soon not talk about it. Lipnik stares at him. His smile has disappeared. There is a long beat. Lou Breeze clears his throat. He apparently feels obliged to fill the silence.

direction.raw_text: Mr. Lipnik, please BARTON I  Mr. Lipnik LIPNIK KISS THIS MAN'S FEET!! Lou, aghast, looks at Barton. Barton, aghast, can only return the same stunned look. Lipnik snarls at Lou:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Lipnik, I LIPNIK I apologize, Barton.

direction.raw_text: No no, Mr. Breeze has actually been a great help LIPNIK You don't have to cover for him. It's noble of you, but these things happen in business.

direction.raw_text: Mr. Lipnik, I really would feel much better if you could reconsider LIPNIK Ah, forget it, kid. I want you to pull this out of your head. If that sonofabitch wouldn't apologize to you, goddammit, I will. I respect your artistry and your methods, and if you can't fill us in yet, well hell, we should be kissing your feet for your fine efforts. He gets down on his knees in front of Barton.

direction.raw_text: The cut has a hard musical sting. Out of the sting comes a loud but distorted thumping noise. We are looking down, high angle, form one corner of the room. We are presented with a motionless tableau: Barton sits, hunched, in the far corner, elbows on knees, staring at the bed in front of him. He wears only trousers and a T-shirt and his body and face glisten with sweat. The bed's sheets have been stripped and the ratty gray mattress has an enormous rust-red stain in the middle. After a beat, in the foreground, the only motion in the scene: A bead of tacky yellow wall-sweat dribbles down the near wall. Silence, then the thumping repeats, resolving itself to a knock at the door. Barton rises slowly and crosses to the door.

direction.raw_text: Barton opens it to Charlie, who is dressed in a baggy suit, his hair slicked back, a tan fedora pushed back on his head. It is the first time we have seen him well turned out. A battered briefcase is on the floor next to him. He holds a parcel in his left hand, about one foot square, wrapped in brown paper and tied up with twine.

direction.raw_text: Barton. Can I come in? Barton stands back from the door and Charlie picks up his briefcase and enters.

direction.raw_text: Jesus, Charlie, I...

direction.raw_text: Charlie! I've got no one else here! You're the only person I know in Los Angeles... He starts weeping
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...that I can talk to. Charlie, also disturbed and unhappy, wraps both arms around Barton. Barton sobs unashamedly into his shoulder. Charlie is somber.

direction.raw_text: It's okay... It's okay...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie, I feel like I'm going crazy like I'm losing my mind. I don't know what to do... I didn't do it, believe me. I'm sure of that, Charlie. I just... His breath comes in short gasping heaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I just don't know what... to do
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You gotta get a grip on, brother. You gotta just carry on  just for a few days, till I get back. Try and stay here, keep your door locked. Don't talk to anyone. We just gotta keep our heads and we'll figure it out.

direction.raw_text: Yeah, but Charlie CHARLIE Dammit, don't argue with me. You asked me to believe you  well I do. Now don't argue with me. He looks at Barton for a beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Look, pal  can you do something for me? Charlie hands him his parcel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Keep this for me, till I get back. Barton, snuffling, accepts the package.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...It's just personal stuff. I don't wanna drag it with me, but I don't trust 'em downstairs, and I'd like to think it's in good hands. Still snuffling:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, Charlie.

direction.raw_text: Funny, huh, when everything that's important to a guy, everything he wants to keep from a lifetime  when he can fit it into a little box like that. I guess... I guess it's kind of pathetic. Wallowing in self-pity:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's more than I've got.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, keep it for me. Maybe it'll bring you good luck. Yeah, it'll help you finish your script. You'll think about me... He thumps his chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Make me your wrestler. Then you'll lick that story of yours. Barton is tearfully sincere:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, Charlie. Charlie solemnly thrusts out his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, well, see you soon, friend. You're gonna be fine. Barton shakes. As they walk to the door:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll be back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry about that, compadre. I'll be back. Barton shuts the door behind Charlie, locks it, and turns around.

direction.raw_text: The room. The bed. The blood-stained mattress. Barton walks across the room and sits carefully at the edge of the bed, avoiding the rust-colored stain. For a long beat, he sits still, but something is building inside. Finally, when we hear the distant ding of the elevator arriving for Charlie, it erupts: Barton sobs, with the unself-conscious grief of an abandoned child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton weeping, alone on the bed, next to the rust-colored stain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With the fade in, the sound of the surf mixes up. We pan down the picture to discover that a snapshot has been tucked into a corner of the picture frame: it is the snap of Charlie, smiling and waving, with his foot up on the running board of the 1939 Ford roadster.

direction.raw_text: Sitting at the desk, staring at the picture. From his glazed eyes and the way his mouth hangs open, we may assume he has been staring at the picture for some time. He notices something on the desk and picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Holy Bible  Placed by the Gideons. Barton opens it, randomly, to the Book of Daniel. The text is set in ornately Gothic type.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . And the king, Nebuchadnezzar, answered and said to the Chaldeans, I recall not my dream; if ye will not make known unto me my dream, and its interpretation, ye shall be cut in pieces, and of your tents shall be made a dunghill."

direction.raw_text: Staring at the passage. His mouth hangs open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton riffles to the first page. In bold type at the top:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Underneath, in the same ornately Gothic type: "Chapter One 1. Fade in on a tenement building on Manhattan's Lower East Side.  Faint traffic noise is audible; 2. As is the cry of fishmongers."

direction.raw_text: Squinting at the page through bloodshot eyes. His mouth hangs open.

direction.raw_text: At the cut the harsh clackety-clack of typing bangs in. Sunlight burns against the sheers of Barton's window, making it a painfully bright patch in the room which itself remains fairly dim. Barton sits at the secretary, typing furiously. He finishes a page, yanks it out of the carriage, and places it face-down on a short stack of face-down pages. He feeds in a blank sheet and resumes his rapid typing. He is sweating, unshaven, and more haggard even than when we left him the previous night. The telephone rings. After several rings Barton stops typing and answers it, absently, still looking at his work. His voice is hoarse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello... Chet... Who?... He puts the receiver down on the desk, leans over the typewriter, and examines something he has just written. He picks the phone back up and listens for a beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are tracking toward the paper-wrapped parcel that sits on the nightstand next to Barton's bed. Barton enters and picks it up. He holds it for a beat, looking at it, then brings it over to the secretary and sits. He shakes it. No sound; whatever is inside is well packed. Barton holds it up to his ear and listens for a long beat, as if it were a seashell and he is listening for the surf. Finally he puts it on his desk, beneath the picture of the bathing beauty, and starts typing, quickly and steadily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some time later; Barton still types. He is face to us; beyond him we can see the bed with its rust-colored stain. The phone rings. Barton ignores it. It continues to ring. Barton rises and exits frame; we hold on to the bed in the background. We hear Barton's footsteps on the bathroom tile as the phone continues ringing. Barton sits back into frame stuffing cotton into each ear. He resumes typing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton typing. The desk trembles under the working of the typewriter.  Charlie's parcel chatters. Barton takes a finished page out of the carriage and places it face down on the growing stack to his right. He feeds in a new page. We hear the muted ding of the elevator down the hall. Barton resumes typing. We hear a knock on Barton's door. Barton does not react, apparently not hearing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are close on the bottom of the door. Someone in the hallway is sliding a note beneath the door; then his shadow disappears and his footsteps recede. The note is a printed message headed: "While You Were Out... " Underneath are the printed words: "You were called by" and, handwritten in the space following: "Mr. Ben Geisler." Handwritten below, in the message space: "Thank you. Lipnik loved your meeting. Keep up the good work." Barton's offscreen typing continues steadily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A perfectly symmetrical wide low angle shot of the empty hall.  Shoes are set put in front of each door except for one in the middle background. At the cut in we hear faint, regular typing. We hold for a beat. There is no motion. The long, empty hall. The distant typing. We hold. The typing stops. There is a beat of quiet. It is broken by the sound of a door opening. It is the shoeless door in the middle background. A hand reaches out to place a pair of shoes in the doorway. The hand withdraws. The door closes. A short beat of silence. The distant typing resumes. The long empty hall. The distant typing. FADE OUT OVER THE BLACK We hear the distant sound of a woman's voice, tinny and indistinct.

From his right hand his briefcase dangles. He stands motionless, facing us. There is something monumental in his posture, shoulders thrown back.

His face is a reddening grimace. With a shriek of protest, the metal gives. The bar to which Barton is handcuffed had come loose at the top and Barton slides the cuff off it, free.
