direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie stands in front of the door to his room, his briefcase dangling from one hand, his other hand fumbling in his pocket for his key. With his hat pushed back on his head and his shoulders slumped with fatigue, he could be any drummer returning to any hotel after a long hard day on the road. He opens the door and goes into his room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and walks up the hallway, his script in one hand, the parcel in the other. A horrible moaning sound  almost human  can be heard under the roar of the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are tracking laterally across the lobby of an executive building. From offscreen we hear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fink! Morris or Lillian Fink! Eighty- five Fulton Street! Filtered through phone:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand that, sir BARTON Or Uncle Dave! Our track has brought Barton into frame in the foreground, unshaven, unkempt, bellowing into the telephone. In a hallway in the background, a secretary gestures for Barton to hurry up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand that, sir, but there's still no answer. Shall I check for trouble on the line? Barton slams down the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barton enters, still clinging on to Charlie's parcel. Lou Breeze stands in one corner censoriously watching Barton. Lipnik is at the far end of the room, gazing out the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Lipnik.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Colonel Lipnik, if you don't mind. He turns to face Barton and we see that he is wearing a smartly pressed uniform with a lot of fruit salad on the chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Siddown. Barton takes a seat facing Lipnik's desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I was commissioned yesterday in the Army Reserve. Henry Morgenthau arranged it. He's a dear friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Congratulations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually it hasn't officially gone through yet. Had wardrobe whip this up. You gotta pull teeth to get anything done in this town. I can understand a little red tape in peacetime, but now it's all-out warfare against the Japs. Little yellow bastards.  They'd love to see me sit this one out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir, they LIPNIK Anyway, I had Lou read your script for me. He taps distastefully at the script on his desk, which has a slightly charred title page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...I gotta tell you, Fink. It won't wash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With all due respect, sir, I think it's the best work I've done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't gas me, Fink. If you're opinion mattered, then I guess I'd resign and let YOU run the the studio. It doesn't and you won't, and the lunatics are not going to run THIS particular asylum. So let's put a stop to THAT rumor right now. Listlessly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had to call Beery this morning, let him know we were pushing the picture back.  After all I'd told him about quality, about that Barton Fink feeling. How disappointed we were. Wally was heartbroken. The man was devastated. He was  well, I didn't actually call him, Lou did. But that's a fair description, isn't it Lou?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Colonel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell, I could take you through it step by step, explain why your story stinks, but I won't insult your intelligence. Well all right, first of all: This is a wrestling picture; the audience wants to see action, drama, wrestling, and plenty of it. They don't wanna see a guy wrestling with his soul  well, all right, a little bit, for the critics  but you make it the carrot that wags the dog. Too much of it and they head for exits and I don't blame 'em. There's plenty of poetry right inside that ring, Fink. Look at "Hell Ten Feet Square".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Blood, Sweat, and Canvas".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at "Blood, Sweat, and Canvas". These are big movies, Fink. About big men, in tights  both physically and mentally. But especially physically. We don't put Wallace Beery in some fruity movie about suffering  I thought we were together on that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry if I let you down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't let ME down. Or even Lou. We don't live or die by what you scribble, Fink. You let Ben Geisler down. He liked you. Trusted you. And that's why he's gone. Fired.  That guy had a heart as big as the outdoors, and you fucked him. He tried to convince me to fire you too, but that would be too easy. No, you're under contract and you're gonna stay that way.  Anything you write will be the property of Capitol Pictures. And Capitol Pictures will not produce anything you write. Not until you grow up a little. You ain't no writer, Fink  you're a goddamn write-off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I tried to show you something beautiful.  Something about all of US This sets Lipnik off:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You arrogant sonofabitch!  You think you're the only writer who can give me that Barton Fink feeling?!  I got twenty writers under contract that I can ask for a Finktype thing from. You swell-headed hypocrite!  You just don't get it, do you?  You think the whole world revolves inside whatever rattles inside that little kike head of yours. Get him outta my sight, Lou. Make sure he stays in town, though; he's still under contract. I want you in town, Fink, and outta my sight. Now get lost. There's a war on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crashing against the Pacific shore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At midday, almost deserted. In the distance we see Barton walking. The paper-wrapped parcel swings from the twine in his left hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks a few more paces and sits down on the sand, looking out to see. His gaze shifts to one side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Down the beach, a bathing beauty walks along the edge of the water. She looks much like the picture on the wall in Barton's hotel room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stares, transfixed, at the woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very beautiful, backlit by the sun, approaching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Following her with his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her eyes meet Barton's. She says something, but her voice is lost in the crash of the surf. Barton cups a hand to his ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said it's a beautiful day...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes... It is...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's in the box? Barton shrugs and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't it yours?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I don't know... She nods and sits down on the sand several paces away from him, facing the water but looking back over her shoulder at Barton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...You're very beautiful. Are you in pictures? She laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be silly. She turns away to look out at the sea.
direction.name: direction
